chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Tip-toe walking
chapter.summary: Covers when to consider community management or specialist referral for a child with tip-toe walking.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth to 16 years.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I consider referring a child with tip toe walking?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Management in the community (for example by a physiotherapist or podiatrist with paediatric expertise) is usually appropriate for a child with tip toe walking if all of the following are present:
    • They are: 
      • Well with no red flag features and are less than 3 years old. 
      • Able to walk with heel strike (suggests idiopathic toe walking) and squat to play on the floor with their heels on the floor. 
      • Well coordinated when walking or running on toes; no limp. 
      • Able to jump (in a school-age child). 
    • They have:
      • Intermittent and symmetrical toe walking. 
      • No pain in their legs or joints. 
      • No risk factors. 
      • Normal development with no regression. 
      • Normal examination; no contractures. 
      • No functional impairment (for example play, walking). 
  • Consider referring children with tip toe walking for specialist assessment, using clinical judgement to determine the urgency, if any of the following are present: 
    • Red flag features.
    • Toe walking persisting over 3 years of age, especially if they are unable to: 
      • Jump (in a school-age child).
      • Squat or stand with their heels on the floor.
      • Stand from sitting on the floor without using their hands.
    • Asymmetric toe walking.
    • Toe walking present for at least half the time they are ambulant.
    • Toe walking in response to pain. 
    • Functional problems (for example tripping, difficulty keeping up with peers). 
    • Changes in gait pattern, such as recent onset of toe walking, having previously walked normally. 
    • Delay or regression in motor or developmental milestones.  
    • A diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder, cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, or global developmental delay, or a history of admission to neonatal intensive care after birth.
    • A family history of muscle disease including muscular dystrophy. 
    • A family history of metabolic or storage disease or suggestive features (for example multisystem disease - recurrent ear infection or upper airway infection, grommets, snoring, cardiac defect, dysmorphism). 
    • Abnormal examination findings including:
      • Not able to heel strike due to high calf tone or contractures. 
      • Abnormal neurological examination, particularly with regard to tone, reflexes, and muscle bulk. 
      • Positive Gower's sign getting up from the floor.
      • Leg length discrepancy.
      • Limited eye contact, rituals (for example lining up toys, rocking).
      • Joint pain, swelling, stiffness, clumsiness, limp, weakness.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Community management

  • The recommendation on when community management is usually appropriate is based on musculoskeletal triage guidance for children and young people [RightPath, 2017; RightPath, 2019] and expert opinion in a review article on the consultation for a child with toe walking [Sivaramakrishnan and Seal, 2015]. 
    • Experts are of the opinion that observation and reassurance is appropriate management for children aged less than 3 years with idiopathic toe walking and that intervention is not always needed [Sivaramakrishnan and Seal, 2015; Ruzbarsky et al, 2016; Morozova et al, 2017].  
    • For idiopathic toe walking, there is little evidence that physical therapy and home stretching have an effect on the ankle range of motion or toe walking [Ruzbarsky et al, 2016]. Some experts suggest conservative management with bracing, serial casting, and botulinum toxin injection, but advise surgical intervention be used only for children with toe walking and severe functional deficits [Morozova et al, 2017]. 

Referral

  • The recommendation on when to consider referral is based on musculoskeletal triage guidance for children and young people [RightPath, 2017], National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidance: Cerebral palsy in under 25s: assessment and management [NICE, 2017], an explanation of the pGALS (paediatric Gait, Arms, Legs, and Spine) examination [Foster, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles [Bellman et al, 2013; Sivaramakrishnan and Seal, 2015; Ruzbarsky et al, 2016; Morozova et al, 2017].  
    • NICE advise referring children with persistent toe walking to a child development service for further assessment [NICE, 2017]. Opinion from other experts is in line with this, suggesting a review of the diagnosis in a child with toe walking persisting over 3 years of age or functional problems, and advising consideration of referral for a formal neurological assessment (because of the association with neurological problems and the fact that examination findings can be subtle) [Sivaramakrishnan and Seal, 2015; Ruzbarsky et al, 2016].
    • Further evaluation is also needed for children with: 
      • A change in gait pattern having previously walked normally — idiopathic toe walking is usually present as soon as children learn to walk, but in some neuromuscular conditions, symptoms may develop over time [Ruzbarsky et al, 2016].  
      • A family history of muscle disease — muscle biopsy may be required for diagnosis [Ruzbarsky et al, 2016].  
      • Inability to heel strike — this is associated with non-idiopathic causes [Ruzbarsky et al, 2016]. 
      • Increased muscle tone, decreased muscle strength, reduced motor control, impaired balance or coordination, and asymmetric toe walking — may suggest cerebral palsy [Morozova et al, 2017].  
    • The choice of specialist will depend on the underlying problem, for example a paediatric neurologist for peripheral neuropathy or movement disorders, or paediatric neurology/neuromuscular service for suspected muscle disorders [Sivaramakrishnan and Seal, 2015]. The appropriate treatment will be based on the child's age, underlying cause, and the severity of any tendon contracture [Ruzbarsky et al, 2016].
